content.description: Start matched on obvious flat edge. Work your way straight up.
content.location: On Trail Side of Bouchard Boulder. One of the first boulders you'll see coming up from the hiking Trail.

content.description: Start on crimps in left leaning seam. Go straight up through good holds to top.
content.location: On left side of the Silent Boulder.

content.description: Start matched on obvious jug. Head straight up through some crimps and a slopey lip.
content.location: On back side of Silent Boulder.

content.description: Start on suspended block with a good left hand on arete and right on decent sidepull. Figure out what to do with your feet and head up arete to top.
content.protection: A few pads maybe a spotter.
content.location: Just up and right of "The Silent Boulder" in a small pile of boulders.

content.description: Start sitting with hands on either side of perched block. Using pedestal for feet figure out how to pull on and climb straight up.
content.location: Up and right of "The Silent Boulder" in a small pile of boulders.

content.description: One of the most aesthetic lines in the valley.  The picture does not do the steep angle of this boulder justice. Sit start at the bottom of the laser arete with your left hand on a sharp incut and your right on a perfect one pad edge.  Make big powerful moves up the arete on excellent edges culminating in a large left throw.  Top out on sharp edges.  Note:  I am adding this route upon the request of my buddy.  We have asked around on the history of this boulder and haven't heard of a recorded ascent.  That being said the aesthetic of the boulder leads us to believe that someone may have climbed it at some point (Dave G??). If anyone has information regarding this boulder please let us know!
content.protection: Flat landing that can be protected by 2.5 pads. There is a swing potential.
content.location: Locate the old blue blazed trail that intersects through the talus field.  Follow this trail until you come across a dried up riverbed.  Take a right off the trail and walk uphill until you see a large cluster of boulders.  Dieseltown is located furthest up the hill in this cluster.

content.description: The bouldering potential in the Mount Washington Valley is endless in quantity and quality. The boulders located underneath the Guides Wall have both of these attributes. Located in a large talus field, the boulders are rather close together which makes access and circuit potential easy. The talus field has a mixture of low and highballs, with most boulders having nice flat landings. There is evidence of people climbing here in the past, but many boulders await exploration. The best part is that little brushing is required to put up new lines!Routes can be added on an individual basis, but once more get established sub-areas may have to be employed to efficiently organize this large talus field.
